newsitem.title: UK: No sign of BOE intervention on stg yet - traders.
newsitem.headline: No sign of BOE intervention on stg yet - traders.

text.p: Sterling's surge above three marks for the first time in more than six years encountered no resistance from the Bank of England on Friday, traders said.
"The dealers here have been trawling for signs of the central banks all day but there has been no sign whatsoever," said one analyst at a major UK bank here.
An official at the Bank of England declined to comment on the issue.
Sterling climbed to 3.0010 marks, the strongest it has been since October 1990. It was at 2.9965/75 at 1500 GMT from 2.9566/76 late Thursday in Europe.

Cable climbed as high as $1.6986, its best showing since January 10. It was last at $1.6945/50 from $1.6882/92 Thursday. The pound's trade-weighted index rose to 104.9, the highest it has been since October 1990.
Analysts said the Bank of England will be wary of taking on sterling bulls too aggressively until there is a fundamental reason for the pound to reverse its gains.

"A set piece battle to defend any particular level is futile given the market's current mood," said Mark Cliffe, chief international economist at HSBC Markets. "You need weak data or a material change in policy before it becomes worthwhile."
Until then any sales of pounds by the Bank of England will be aimed at smoothing sterling volatility, he said. -- Swaha Pattanaik, London newsroom +44 171 542 6284
